statement.p: Find the present value of a 20-year annuity with annual payments which pays 600 immediately and each subsequent payment is 5% greater than the preceding payment. The annual effective rate of interest is 10.25%. Answer to the nearest dollar.

Annual deposits are made into a fund at the beginning of each year for 10 years. The first 5 deposits are 1000 each and deposits increase by 5% per year thereafter. If the fund earns 8% effective, find the accumulated value at the end of 10 years. Answer to the nearest dollar.

A perpetuity makes payments starting five years from today. The first payment is 1000 and each payment thereafter increases byk% per year. The present value of this perpetuity is equal to 4096 when computed at \iota = 25\%. Find k.

Al and Sal are twins. Al is given a fifteen-year annuity with end-of-year payments. The first payment Al receives, precisely one year from the date he is given the annuity, is for 100, and then subsequent payments decrease by 4% annually. Sal is given an n-year level annuity that has the same present value as Al's when the present values are calculated using \iota = 5\%. Again, calculated using \iota = 5\%, the accumulated value at the end of n years of Sal's annuity is 1,626.29. Find the common present value of the two annuities and then find n.

An employee currently is aged 40, earns 40,000 per year, and expects to receive 3% annual raises at the end of each year for the next 25 years. The employee decides to contribute 4% of annual salary at the beginning of each year for the next 25 years into a retirement plan. How much will be available for retirement at age 65 if the fund can earn a 5% effective rate of interest? Answer to the nearest dollar.

Annual end-of-year deposits are made to a fund paying an annual effective rate of interest of 6%. The first deposit is 1,000 and then they go up by 3% annually. Interest from the 6% account is paid out annually and is reinvested at an annual effective discount rate of 4%. At the end of the thirty years, the funds are liquidated. Find the investor's accumulated value at the time of the liquidation.

A series of payments is made at the beginning of each year for 20 years with the first payment being 100. Each subsequent payment through the tenth year increases by 5% from the previous payment. After the tenth payment, each payment decreases by 5% from the previous payment. Calculate the present value of these payments at the time the first payment is made using an annual effective rate of 7%. Answer to the nearest dollar.

A forward contract is a contract to purchase something at a point in the future. If payment is made at the time of the contract, this is called a prepaid forward. For a share of stock, the price of a prepaid forward is the current stock price minus the present value of the dividends that will be issued prior to delivery. This is an adjustment due to the fact that the buyer does not get any of the dividends issued prior to delivery of the stock.

A share of GOT, stock in the Iron Bank of Braavos, currently costs 50. The bank will issue quarterly dividends starting in 2 months. The first dividend will be 1.5, and each dividend will grow by 3% over the previous dividend. Find the price of a 3-year prepaid forward on GOT assuming \iota^{(2)} = 16\%.

A share of SKI, stock in Stark Industries, currently costs 100. The company will issue semi-annual dividends, with the first dividend payout in 4 months. The first dividend will be 2.75, and each dividend will grow by 5% over the previous dividend. Find the price of a 5-year prepaid forward on SKI (see ) assuming a constant annual force of interest \delta = 6\%.

Jeff and Jason spend X dollars each to purchase annuities. Jeff buys a perpetuity-immediate, which makes annual payments of 30. Jason buys a 10-year annuity-immediate, also with annual payments. The first payment is 53, with each subsequent payment k% larger than the previous year's payment. Both annuities use an effective annual interest rate of k%. Calculate k.

Mike buys a perpetuity-immediate with varying annual payments. During the first 5 years, the payment is constant and equal to 10. Beginning in Year 6, the payments start to increase. For year 6 and all future years, the current year's payment is K% larger than the previous year's payment. At an effective annual interest rate of 9.2%, the perpetuity has a present value of 167.50. Calculate K, given K < 9.2.

Consider an annuity-immediate with monthly payments for twenty years. The payments are level in the course of each year, then increase by 2% for the next year. Find the present value of this annuity if the initial payment is 1000 and \iota = 4\%.

A senior executive is offered a buyout package by her company that will pay her a monthly benefit for the next 20 years. Monthly benefits will remain constant within each of the 20 years. At the end of each 12-month period, the monthly benefits will be adjusted upwards to reflect the percentage increase in the CPI. You are given:

li.p: The first monthly benefit is R and will be paid one month from today.
The CPI increases 3.2% per year forever.

statement.p: At an effective interest rate of 6%, the buyout package has a value of 100,000. Calculate R.

Smith has 100,000 with which she buys a perpetuity on January 1, 2005. Suppose that \iota = 0.045 and the perpetuity has annual payments beginning January 1, 2006. The first three payments are 2000 each, the next three payments are 2000(1+r) each, increasing forever by a factor of 1+r every three years. What is r?

A share of James Brown Inc (JBI) is trading for 125. The company issues annual dividends. The dividend at the end of this year will be 5, and each subsequent dividend will be 3% larger. What effective annual interest rate is implied by this price?

George Clinton and Chaka Khan each plan to invest X. George Clinton is going to purchase a share of FNK (Funk the Rockhouse Inc.). FNK will start paying out semiannual dividends in 6 years. The first dividend will be for K, each each dividend thereafter will increase by approximately 6.132%. Chaka Khan will purchase a level-payment annuity, with n quarterly payments of K beginning 3 months from the time of purchase. The interest rate is \iota^{(2)} = 0.16. Find n.

Olga buys a 5-year increasing annuity for X. Olga will receive 2 at the end of the first month, 4 at the end of the second month, and for each month thereafter the payment increases by 2. The nominal interest rate is 9% convertible quarterly. Calculate X.

If X is the present value of a perpetuity of 1 per year with the first payment at the end of the second year and 20X is the present value of a series of annual payments 1,2,3, \ldots with the first payment at the end of the third year, find d.

Payments of 5,000 are made into a fund at the beginning of each year for ten years. The fund is invested at an annual effective rate of \iota. The interest generated is reinvested at 10%. The total accumulated value at the end of ten years is 100,000. Find \iota.

introduction.p: There are two perpetuities. The first has level payments of p at the end of each year. The second is increasing such that payments are q, 2q, 3q, \ldots. Find the rate of interest which will make the difference in present value between these perpetuities:

statement.p: Bob deposits 11,000 at the beginning of each year for six years in a fund earning an effective annual rate of 7.5%. The interest from this fund can only be reinvested at an effective annual rate of 5%. Find the accumulated value of Bob's investments at the end of thirteen years.

Susan invests Z at the end of each year for seven years at an effective annual interest rate of 5%. The interest credited at the end of each year is reinvested at an effective annual rate of 6%. The accumulated value at the end of seven years is X. Lori invests Z at the end of each year for 14 years at an effective annual interest rate of 2.5%. The interest credited at the end of each year is reinvested at an effective annual rate of 3%. The accumulated value at the end of 14 years is Y. Calculate Y/X.

A perpetuity costs 77.1 and makes annual payments at the end of the year. The perpetuity pays 1 at the end of year 2, 2 at the end of year 3, \ldots, n at the end of year (n+1). After year (n+1), the payments remain constant at n. The effective annual interest rate is 10.5%. Calculate n.

Erik receives an eight-year annuity-immediate with monthly payments. The first payment is 300 and payments increase by 6 each month. The payments are deposited in an account earning interest at a nominal rate of 6% convertible monthly. What is the balance in the account at the end of the eight years?

A perpetuity has annual payments. The first payment is for 320 and then payments increase by 30 each year until they become level at 980. Find the value of this annuity at the time of the first payment using an effective annual interest of 4%.
A perpetuity-immediate has annual payments of 1,3,5,7, \ldots. If the present value of the sixth and seventh payments are equal, find the present value of the perpetuity.
An annuity immediate has semiannual payments of 800, 750, 700, \ldots, 350 at \iota^{(2)} = 0.16. If a_{\angl{10} 0.08} = A, find the present value of the annuity in terms of A.

Sandy purchases a perpetuity-immediate that makes annual payments. The first payment is 100, and each payment thereafter increases by 10. Danny purchases a perpetuity-due which makes annual payments of 180. Using the same effective annual interest rate, \iota > 0, the present value of both perpetuities are equal. Calculate \iota.

1000 is deposited into Fund X, which earns an effective annual interest rate of 6%. At the end of each year, the interest earned plus an additional 100 is withdrawn from the fund. At the end of the tenth year, the fund is depleted. The annual withdrawals of interest and principal are deposited into Fund Y, which earns an effective annual rate of 9%. Determine the accumulated value of Fund Y at the end of year 10.

A loan of 12,000 is repaid by 36 monthly payments starting one month after the loan. The first 12 payments are 395+X each, the next twelve payments are 395 each, and the final payments are 395-X each. If \iota^{(12)} = 0.12, find X.

Victor invests 300 into a bank account at the beginning of each year for 20 years. The account pays out interest at the end of every year at an effective annual interest rate of \iota%. The interest is reinvested at an effective annual rate of \frac{\iota}{2}%. The yield rate on the entire investment over the 20 year period is 8% effective annual. Determine \iota.

NOTE: The term "yield rate" here means the interest rate that one would use for an annuity (without reinvestment) with payments of 300 that would result in the same future value (or present value) as the scheme that Victor engaged in (was this me??).
Joe can purchase one of two annuities:
ANNUITY 1: A 10-year decreasing annuity-immediate with annual payments of 10, 9, 8, \ldots, 1.
ANNUITY 2: A perpetuity-immediate with annual payments. The perpetuity pays 1 in year 1, 2 in year 2, 3 in year 3, \ldots, and 11 in year 11. After year 11, the payments remain constant at 11.
At an effective annual interest rate of \iota, the present value of Annuity 2 is twice the present value of Annuity 1. Calculate the value of Annuity 1.
